conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the block and the plank to determine the condition for F1.
Identify forces: gravitational force mg downward, normal force N perpendicular to plank, frictional force f horizontally left, applied force F1 left, applied force F2 upward.
Maximum static friction fs and kinetic friction fk are both given by f = mu N.
For block to move upward, vertical force F2 must be greater than gravitational force mg, so F2 > mg.
Horizontal force F1 must overcome frictional force f, given by f = mu N.
Normal force N is due to weight of block and plank, with plank weight Mg.
Total normal force N is N = mg + Mg.
Calculate N: (0.80 kg + 0.40 kg) x 10 m/s^2 = 12 N; f = mu N = 0.20 x 12 N = 2.4 N.
For block to move upward, F1 must be greater than frictional force f, so F1 > 2.4 N.
Condition for F1 is F1 > 2.4 N.
